title: 112_s1785
content: The Act is titled the "Back to Work Tax Credit" and includes provisions for long-term unemployed workers to receive work opportunity tax credits. The "Back to Work Tax Credit" Act includes provisions for qualified long-term unemployed individuals to receive tax credits of $10,000 per year. The "Back to Work Tax Credit" Act defines a qualified long-term unemployed individual as someone who was not a student for at least 6 months prior to the hiring date and had aggregate periods of unemployment totaling 6 months or more. The "Back to Work Tax Credit" Act allows for simplified certification for qualified long-term unemployed individuals who have received unemployment compensation for at least 6 months. The "Back to Work Tax Credit" Act allows for simplified certification for qualified long-term unemployed individuals who have received unemployment compensation for at least 6 months. The Secretary may provide alternative methods for certification under certain circumstances. Additionally, tax-exempt employers may be eligible for a credit under specific conditions. The work opportunity credit for tax-exempt employers is determined based on the lesser of the credit related to hiring qualified long-term unemployed individuals or the employer's payroll taxes for the year. For tax-exempt employers, the credit amount is adjusted to 26 percent and 16.25 percent in specific sections of the tax code. The term 'tax-exempt employer' refers to organizations exempt from taxation under section 501(c) or public higher education institutions. 'Payroll taxes' include amounts withheld from employees under section 3402(a). The Secretary of the Treasury will pay mirror code possessions amounts equal to their loss due to amendments made by the section. The Secretary of the Treasury will pay possessions of the United States without a mirror code tax system estimated amounts equal to the credits they would have received under the amendments made by this section. The Treasury will distribute payments to possessions of the United States. No increase in the credit under the Internal Revenue Code will be taken into account for individuals eligible for a credit or payment under the amendments. Definitions and special rules apply. The Treasury will distribute payments to possessions of the United States, including American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, and the United States Virgin Islands. The term "mirror code tax system" refers to the income tax system of these possessions, where residents' tax liability is determined by reference to the income tax laws of the United States. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who start working for the employer after the enactment of this Act.
